summary: This is a court order from Judge Alison J. Nathan in the case of United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, setting a firm trial date of November 29, 2021, and establishing a detailed pre-trial schedule for jury selection, motions, and conferences. It outlines procedural steps including juror questionnaire administration, voir dire, and deadlines for legal submissions.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20-CR-330) for which this order sets the trial schedule.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case who issued this order, setting the trial date and pre-trial schedule.

events.title: Trial Commencement
events.description: The jury trial in United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell is scheduled to commence.

events.title: Telephone Conference on Jury Selection
events.description: The parties are ordered to appear for a telephone conference to discuss jury selection matters.

events.title: In-Person Pretrial Conference
events.description: The parties are ordered to appear for an in-person pretrial conference.

events.title: Juror Questionnaire Administration
events.description: Dates provided by the Clerk's Office for administering a juror questionnaire (also Nov 5 and 12).

events.title: Voir Dire
events.description: Dates provided by the Clerk's Office for conducting voir dire (through Nov 19).

events.title: Previous Schedule Order
events.description: The Court had previously set a schedule on this date, which is now being amended.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: A firm trial date for Ghislaine Maxwell's criminal case was set for November 29, 2021.
The order establishes a detailed pre-trial schedule, including deadlines for juror questionnaires (Oct 11), motions in limine (Oct 18), and a joint proposed charge (Oct 27).
Jury selection activities are scheduled for specific dates in November 2021: questionnaire administration (Nov 4, 5, 12) and voir dire (Nov 16-19).
The order references COVID-19 protocols affecting courtroom space and centralized jury trial scheduling in the district.
The document is a formal court order (Docket No. 330) filed on August 27, 2021, by Judge Alison J. Nathan.
